form.current-chamber: IN THE SENATE OF THE UNITED STATES

action.action-desc: Mrs. Gillibrand (for herself and Mr. Hawley) introduced the following bill; which was read twice and referred to the Committee on Homeland Security and Governmental Affairs

form.official-title: To facilitate the implementation of security measures undertaken by the United States Postal Service, and for other purposes.

section.text: This Act may be cited as the Protect Our Letter Carriers Act of 2025.
It is the sense of the Congress that—

paragraph.text: United States Postal Service letter carriers must be protected from acts of violence; and
the Attorney General should vigorously prosecute any case of assault against a postal employee.

section.text: There is authorized to be appropriated $1,400,000,000 for each of fiscal years 2025 through 2029 to the United States Postal Service to carry out, as determined by the United States Postal Service—

paragraph.text: the installation of high security collection boxes; and
the replacement of older versions of the universal mailbox key, also known as the arrow key, with electronic versions.

section.header: Coordination of prosecution of offenses against the United States Postal Service

subsection.text: Section 542 of title 28, United States Code, is amended by adding at the end the following:

The Attorney General shall, in consultation with the United States attorney for the district, appoint in each judicial district an assistant United States attorney with principal responsibility in the district to coordinate and supervise the investigation and prosecution of alleged offenses committed—

paragraph.text: in violation of chapter 83 of title 18;
in violation of sections 2115, 2116, or 2117 of title 18; or
against a carrier or person entrusted with the mail and having custody thereof, in violation of section 111 of title 18.

subsection.text: The Attorney General shall comply with section 542(c) of title 28, United States Code, as added by this Act, not later than 1 year after the date of the enactment of this Act.

section.header: Sentencing guidelines with respect to robbery against a postal employee
section.text: Not later than May 1 following the first year that begins after the date of enactment of this Act, the United States Sentencing Commission shall amend the sentencing guidelines and policy statements promulgated under section 994 of title 28, United States Code, to provide that the assault or robbery of a postal employee, including conduct committed during the immediate flight after the commission of such an assault or robbery if the conduct creates a substantial risk of serious bodily injury, shall be treated in the same manner as the assault of a law enforcement officer.
